# Men's major golf championships

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

"Major tournaments" redirects here. For major tennis tournaments, see [Grand
slam (tennis)](/wiki/Grand_slam_\(tennis\) "Grand slam \(tennis\)").

The **men 's major golf championships**, commonly known as the **Major
Championships** ,[1] and often referred to simply as **the majors** , are the
four most prestigious annual tournaments in professional [golf](/wiki/Golf
"Golf"). In order of play date, they are:

  * April – [Masters Tournament](/wiki/Masters_Tournament "Masters Tournament") (weekend ending 2nd Sunday in April) – hosted as an invitational by and played at [Augusta National Golf Club](/wiki/Augusta_National_Golf_Club "Augusta National Golf Club") in the U.S. state of Georgia.
  * June – [U.S. Open](/wiki/U.S._Open_\(golf\) "U.S. Open \(golf\)") (weekend ending with the 3rd Sunday in June, or Father's Day.) – hosted by the [United States Golf Association](/wiki/United_States_Golf_Association "United States Golf Association") (USGA) and played at various locations in the United States.
  * July – [The Open Championship](/wiki/The_Open_Championship "The Open Championship") (week containing the 3rd Friday in July) – hosted by The R&A, an offshoot of [The Royal and Ancient Golf Club of St Andrews](/wiki/The_Royal_and_Ancient_Golf_Club_of_St_Andrews "The Royal and Ancient Golf Club of St Andrews"), and always played on a [links course](/wiki/Links_course "Links course") at one of ten locations in the United Kingdom.
  * August – [PGA Championship](/wiki/PGA_Championship "PGA Championship") (3rd weekend prior to [Labor Day](/wiki/Labor_Day "Labor Day") weekend, but will be moved to the third weekend of May beginning in 2019)[2] – hosted by the [Professional Golfers' Association of America](/wiki/Professional_Golfers%27_Association_of_America "Professional Golfers' Association of America") and played at various locations in the United States.

##
Importance[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Men%27s_major_golf_championships&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Importance")]

Alongside the biennial [Ryder Cup](/wiki/Ryder_Cup "Ryder Cup") and
[Presidents Cup](/wiki/Presidents_Cup "Presidents Cup") team competitions, the
majors are golf's marquee events. Elite players from all over the world
participate in them, and the reputations of the greatest players in golf
history are largely based on the number and variety of major championship
victories they accumulate. The top prizes are not actually the largest in
golf, being surpassed by [The Players
Championship](/wiki/The_Players_Championship "The Players Championship"),
three of the four [World Golf Championships](/wiki/World_Golf_Championships
"World Golf Championships") events (the [HSBC Champions](/wiki/WGC-
HSBC_Champions "WGC-HSBC Champions"), promoted to WGC status in 2009, has a
top prize comparable to that of the majors), and some other invitational
events. However, winning a major boosts a player's career far more than
winning any other tournament. If he is already a leading player, he will
probably receive large bonuses from his sponsors and may be able to negotiate
better contracts. If he is an unknown, he will immediately be signed up.
Perhaps more importantly, he will receive an exemption from the need to
annually re-qualify for a tour card on his home tour, thus giving a tournament
golfer some security in an unstable profession. Currently, the PGA Tour gives
a five-year exemption to all major winners, while the [European
Tour](/wiki/European_Tour "European Tour") gives a seven-year exemption.

Three of the four majors take place in the United States. The Masters is
played at the same course, [Augusta National Golf
Club](/wiki/Augusta_National_Golf_Club "Augusta National Golf Club"), every
year, while the other three rotate courses (the Open Championship, however, is
always played on a [links course](/wiki/Links_\(golf\) "Links \(golf\)")).
Each of the majors has a distinct history, and they are run by four different
golf organizations, but their special status is recognized worldwide. Major
championship winners receive the maximum possible allocation of 100 points
from the [Official World Golf Ranking](/wiki/Official_World_Golf_Ranking
"Official World Golf Ranking"), which is endorsed by all of the main
[tours](/wiki/Professional_golf_tours "Professional golf tours"), and major
championship prize money is official on the three richest regular (i.e.
under-50) golf tours, the [PGA Tour](/wiki/PGA_Tour "PGA Tour"), [European
Tour](/wiki/European_Tour "European Tour") and [Japan Golf
Tour](/wiki/Japan_Golf_Tour "Japan Golf Tour").

Although the majors are considered prestigious due to their history and
traditions, there are still other non-"major" tournaments which prominently
feature top players competing for purses meeting or exceeding those of the
four traditional majors, such as the [World Golf
Championships](/wiki/World_Golf_Championships "World Golf Championships"), the
[European Tour](/wiki/European_Tour "European Tour")'s [DP World Tour
Championship, Dubai](/wiki/DP_World_Tour_Championship,_Dubai "DP World Tour
Championship, Dubai"), and the PGA Tour's [Players
Championship](/wiki/The_Players_Championship "The Players Championship"). As
The Players has the largest prize fund of any golf event, and is promoted as
the tour's flagship tournament, it is frequently considered to be an
unofficial "fifth major" by players and critics. After the announcement that
the [Evian Masters](/wiki/The_Evian_Championship "The Evian Championship")
would be recognized as the fifth [women's
major](/wiki/Women%27s_major_golf_championships "Women's major golf
championships") by the [LPGA Tour](/wiki/LPGA_Tour "LPGA Tour"), players
shared objections to the concept of having a fifth men's major, owing to the
long-standing traditions that the existing four have established.[3][4]

##
History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Men%27s_major_golf_championships&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: History")]

The majors originally consisted of two British tournaments, [The Open
Championship](/wiki/The_Open_Championship "The Open Championship") and [The
Amateur Championship](/wiki/The_Amateur_Championship "The Amateur
Championship"), and two American tournaments, [the U.S.
Open](/wiki/U.S._Open_\(golf\) "U.S. Open \(golf\)") and the [U.S.
Amateur](/wiki/U.S._Amateur "U.S. Amateur"). With the introduction of the
Masters Tournament in 1934, and the rise of professional golf in the late
1940s and 1950s, the term "major championships" eventually came to describe
the [Masters](/wiki/Masters_Tournament "Masters Tournament"), the U.S. Open,
the Open Championship, and the [PGA Championship](/wiki/PGA_Championship "PGA
Championship"). It is difficult to determine when the definition changed to
include the current four tournaments, although many trace it to Arnold
Palmer's 1960 season. After winning the Masters and the U.S. Open to start the
season, he remarked that if he could win the Open Championship and PGA
Championship to finish the season, he would complete "a grand slam of his own"
to rival [Bobby Jones](/wiki/Bobby_Jones_\(golfer\) "Bobby Jones
\(golfer\)")'s 1930 feat. Until that time, many U.S. players such as Byron
Nelson also considered the [Western Open](/wiki/Western_Open "Western Open")
and the [North and South Open](/wiki/North_and_South_Open "North and South
Open") as two of golf's "majors,"[5] and the [British PGA Matchplay
Championship](/wiki/British_PGA_Matchplay_Championship "British PGA Matchplay
Championship") was as important to British and Commonwealth professionals as
the PGA Championship was to Americans.

During the 1950s, the short-lived [World Championship of
Golf](/wiki/World_Championship_of_Golf "World Championship of Golf") was
viewed as a "major" by its competitors, as its first prize was worth almost
ten times any other event in the game, and it was the first event whose finale
was televised live on U.S. television. The oldest of the majors is The Open
Championship, commonly referred to as the "British Open" outside the United
Kingdom. Dominated by American champions in the 1920s and 1930s, the
comparative explosion in the riches available on the U.S. Tour from the 1940s
onwards meant that the lengthy overseas trip needed to qualify and compete in
the event became increasingly prohibitive for the leading American
professionals. Their regular participation dwindled after the war years. [Ben
Hogan](/wiki/Ben_Hogan "Ben Hogan") entered just once in
[1953](/wiki/1953_Open_Championship "1953 Open Championship") and won, but
never returned. [Sam Snead](/wiki/Sam_Snead "Sam Snead") won in
[1946](/wiki/1946_Open_Championship "1946 Open Championship") but lost money
on the trip (first prize was $600) and did not return until
[1962](/wiki/1962_Open_Championship "1962 Open Championship").

Golf writer [Dan Jenkins](/wiki/Dan_Jenkins "Dan Jenkins"), often seen as the
world authority on majors since he's attended more (200+) than anyone else,
has noted that "the pros didn't talk much about majors back then. I think it
was [Herbert Warren Wind](/wiki/Herbert_Warren_Wind "Herbert Warren Wind") who
starting using the term. He said golfers had to be judged by the major
tournaments they won, but it's not like there was any set number of major
tournaments."[6]

In [1960](/wiki/1960_Open_Championship "1960 Open Championship"), [Arnold
Palmer](/wiki/Arnold_Palmer "Arnold Palmer") entered [The Open
Championship](/wiki/The_Open_Championship "The Open Championship") in an
attempt to emulate Hogan's 1953 feat of winning on his first visit. Though a
runner-up by a stroke in his first attempt, Palmer returned and won the next
two in [1961](/wiki/1961_Open_Championship "1961 Open Championship") and
[1962](/wiki/1962_Open_Championship "1962 Open Championship"). Scheduling
difficulties persisted with the PGA Championship, but more Americans began
competing in the 1960s, restoring the event's prestige (and with it the prize
money that once again made it an attractive prospect to other American pros).
The advent of transatlantic jet travel helped to boost American participation
in The Open. A discussion between Palmer and [Pittsburgh](/wiki/Pittsburgh
"Pittsburgh") golf writer Bob Drum led to the concept of the modern [Grand
Slam of Golf](/wiki/Grand_Slam_\(golf\) "Grand Slam \(golf\)").[7]

In August 2017, after the previous year's edition was scheduled earlier due to
[golf at the 2016 Summer Olympics](/wiki/Golf_at_the_2016_Summer_Olympics
"Golf at the 2016 Summer Olympics"), the PGA of America announced that the PGA
Championship would be moved to late-May beginning in 2019, in between the
Masters and U.S. Open. The PGA Tour concurrently announced that it would move
the Players Championship back to March the same year; as a result, the Players
and the four majors will still be played across five consecutive months.[8][2]

## Television
coverage[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Men%27s_major_golf_championships&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Television coverage")]

### United Kingdom &
Ireland[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Men%27s_major_golf_championships&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: United Kingdom & Ireland")]

In the United Kingdom, [the BBC](/wiki/BBC_Sport "BBC Sport") used to be the
exclusive TV home of the Masters Tournament and the Open Championship, however
from 2011 onwards [Sky Sports](/wiki/Sky_Sports "Sky Sports") has exclusive
live coverage of the first two days of the Masters, with the weekend rounds
shared with the BBC. The U.S. Open is shown exclusively on Sky Sports.
Beginning in 2016, Sky Sports also became the exclusive broadcaster of the
Open Championship; the BBC elected to forego the final year of its
contract.[9] The BBC continues to hold rights to broadcast a nightly
highlights programme.[10]

Sky also held rights to the PGA Championship, but in July 2017, it was
reported that the PGA of America had declined to renew its contract, seeking a
different media model for the tournament in the United Kingdom.[11] The BBC
acquired rights to the PGA Championship for 2017, with most coverage relegated
to [BBC Red Button](/wiki/BBC_Red_Button "BBC Red Button") and the conclusion
of coverage on [BBC Two](/wiki/BBC_Two "BBC Two"). The PGA reached a separate
deal to also stream coverage in the UK via [Facebook Live](/wiki/Facebook_Live
"Facebook Live"), hosted by GiveMeSport.[12] [13]

### United
States[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Men%27s_major_golf_championships&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: United States")]

As none of the majors fall under the direct jurisdiction of tours, broadcast
rights for these events are negotiated separately with each sanctioning body.
All four majors have been broadcast at some point by one of the ["big three"
networks](/wiki/Big_Three_television_networks "Big Three television
networks")—all of whom are currently or have previously been PGA Tour
broadcast partners. In 2015, CBS was the only big three network that held
weekend-round rights to one or more majors, as the remainder, along with early
round coverage of all four, were held either by
[Fox](/wiki/Fox_Broadcasting_Company "Fox Broadcasting Company") or cable
networks.

The Masters has been televised by [CBS](/wiki/PGA_Tour_on_CBS "PGA Tour on
CBS") since [1956](/wiki/1956_Masters_Tournament "1956 Masters Tournament").
Beginning in 1966, [ABC](/wiki/PGA_Tour_on_ABC "PGA Tour on ABC") obtained the
broadcast rights for the other three majors and held them for a quarter
century. The PGA Championship moved to CBS in
[1991](/wiki/1991_PGA_Championship "1991 PGA Championship") and the U.S. Open
returned to [NBC](/wiki/Golf_Channel_on_NBC "Golf Channel on NBC") in
[1995](/wiki/1995_U.S._Open_\(golf\) "1995 U.S. Open \(golf\)").[14][15]

ABC retained The Open Championship as its sole major, but moved its live
coverage on the weekend to sister cable network [ESPN](/wiki/ESPN "ESPN") in
[2010](/wiki/2010_Open_Championship "2010 Open Championship"). In June 2015,
it was announced that NBC and [Golf Channel](/wiki/Golf_Channel "Golf
Channel") would acquire rights to the Open Championship under a 12-year
deal.[16] While the NBC deal was originally to take effect in 2017, ESPN chose
to opt out of its final year of Open rights, so the NBC contract took effect
beginning in [2016](/wiki/2016_Open_Championship "2016 Open Championship")
instead.[9]

The Masters operates under one-year contracts; CBS has been the main TV
partner every year since 1956, with ESPN broadcasting CBS-produced coverage of
the first and second rounds since [2008](/wiki/2008_Masters_Tournament "2008
Masters Tournament"), replacing [USA Network](/wiki/USA_Network "USA
Network"), which had shown the event since the early 1980s.[17] As of 2015,
[Fox Sports](/wiki/Fox_Sports_\(United_States\) "Fox Sports \(United
States\)") holds broadcast rights to the U.S. Open and other USGA events,
replacing NBC and ESPN, with [Fox Sports 1](/wiki/Fox_Sports_1 "Fox Sports 1")
as the primary pay TV outlet.[18] CBS and [Turner Sports](/wiki/Turner_Sports
"Turner Sports") hold rights to the PGA Championship, with
[TNT](/wiki/TNT_\(TV_channel\) "TNT \(TV channel\)") handling early round and
weekend morning coverage, and CBS airing weekend afternoon coverage. Their
respective contracts with the PGA of America run through 2019.[19][20]

## Distinctive characteristics of
majors[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Men%27s_major_golf_championships&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Distinctive characteristics of majors")]

Because each major was developed and is run by a different organization, they
each have different characteristics that set them apart. These involve the
character of the courses used, the composition of the field, and other
idiosyncrasies.

  * The [Masters Tournament](/wiki/Masters_Tournament "Masters Tournament") (sometimes referred to as the U.S. Masters) is the only major that is played at the same course every year ([Augusta National Golf Club](/wiki/Augusta_National_Golf_Club "Augusta National Golf Club")), being the invitational tournament of that club. The Masters invites the smallest field of the majors, generally under 100 players (although, like all the majors, it now ensures entry for all golfers among the world's top 50 prior to the event), and is the only one of the four majors that does not use "alternates" to replace qualified players who do not enter the event (usually due to injury). Former champions have a lifetime invitation to compete, and also included in the field are the current champions of the major amateur championships, and most of the previous year's [PGA Tour](/wiki/PGA_Tour "PGA Tour") winners (winners of "alternate" events held opposite a high-profile tournament _do not_ receive automatic invitations). The traditions of Augusta, such as the awarding of a green jacket to the champion, create a distinctive character for the tournament, as does the course itself, with its lack of primary rough but severely undulating fairways and greens, and punitive use of ponds and creeks on several key holes on the back nine.
  * The [U.S. Open](/wiki/U.S._Open_\(golf\) "U.S. Open \(golf\)") is notorious for being played on difficult courses that have tight fairways, challenging greens, demanding pin positions and thick and high rough, placing a great premium on accuracy, especially with driving and approach play. Additionally, while most regular tour events are played on courses with par 72, the U.S. Open has almost never been held on a par-72 course in recent decades; the [2017 event](/wiki/2017_U.S._Open_\(golf\) "2017 U.S. Open \(golf\)") will be the first since [1992](/wiki/1992_U.S._Open_\(golf\) "1992 U.S. Open \(golf\)") to be played at par 72.[21] During this time, the tournament course has occasionally been played to a par of 71 but most commonly par 70. The U.S. Open is rarely won with a score much under par. The event is the championship of the [United States Golf Association](/wiki/United_States_Golf_Association "United States Golf Association"), and in having a very strict exempt qualifiers list – made up of recent major champions, professionals currently ranked high in the world rankings or on the previous year's money lists around the world, and leading amateurs from recent USGA events – about half of the 156-person field still enters the tournament through two rounds of open qualification events, mostly held in the U.S. but also in Europe and Japan. The U.S. Open has no barrier to entry for either women or junior players, as long as they are a professional or meet amateur handicap requirements. As of 2016, however, no female golfer has yet qualified for the U.S. Open, although in 2006 [Michelle Wie](/wiki/Michelle_Wie "Michelle Wie") made it to the second qualifying stage. The U.S. Open continues to have an 18-hole playoff if players are tied after four rounds. (The Open and PGA Championships use four- and three-hole aggregate playoffs respectively, followed by sudden death if necessary, and most regular events as well as the Masters only have simple sudden-death playoffs.) The Sunday of the Championship has also in recent years fallen on [Father's Day](/wiki/Father%27s_Day_\(United_States\) "Father's Day \(United States\)") (at least as recognized in the US and the UK) which has lent added poignancy to winners' speeches.
  * [The Open Championship](/wiki/The_Open_Championship "The Open Championship") (sometimes referred to as the British Open) is organized by [The R&A](/wiki/The_Royal_and_Ancient_Golf_Club_of_St_Andrews#The_R.26A "The Royal and Ancient Golf Club of St Andrews"), an offshoot of [The Royal and Ancient Golf Club of St Andrews](/wiki/The_Royal_and_Ancient_Golf_Club_of_St_Andrews "The Royal and Ancient Golf Club of St Andrews"), and is typically played on a [links-style course](/wiki/Links_\(golf\) "Links \(golf\)") in the [United Kingdom](/wiki/United_Kingdom "United Kingdom") (primarily [England](/wiki/England "England") or [Scotland](/wiki/Scotland "Scotland")). It carries the prestige of being the oldest professional golf tournament currently in existence and the original "Open" championship (although the very first event was held only for British professionals). It is respected for maintaining the tradition of links play that dates back to the very invention of the game in Scotland. Links courses are generally typified as coastal, flat and often very windswept, with the fairways cut through dune grass and gorse bushes that make up the "rough", and have deep bunkers. The course is generally not "doctored" to make it more difficult, effectively making the variable weather the main external influence on the field's score.[22] As well as exempting from qualifying recent professional major and amateur champions, all former Open Championship winners under age 60, and leading players from the world rankings, the R&A ensures that leading golfers from around the globe are given the chance to enter by holding qualifying events on all continents, as well as holding final qualifying events around the UK in the weeks prior to the main tournament. The champion receives (and has his name inscribed on the base of) the famous [Claret Jug](/wiki/Claret_Jug "Claret Jug"), a trophy that dates back to 1872 (champions from 1860 until 1871 received instead a championship belt, much like a champion professional boxer's belt nowadays) and the engraving of the champions' name on the trophy prior to them receiving it is, in itself, one of the traditions of the closing ceremony of the championship, as is the award of the silver medal to the leading amateur player to have made the cut to play the last 36 holes.
  * The [PGA Championship](/wiki/PGA_Championship "PGA Championship") (sometimes referred to as the U.S. PGA) is traditionally played at a parkland club in the United States, and the courses chosen tend to be as difficult as those chosen for the U.S. Open, with several, such as [Baltusrol Golf Club](/wiki/Baltusrol_Golf_Club "Baltusrol Golf Club"), Medinah Country Club, [Oakland Hills Country Club](/wiki/Oakland_Hills_Country_Club "Oakland Hills Country Club"), [Oak Hill Country Club](/wiki/Oak_Hill_Country_Club "Oak Hill Country Club"), and [Winged Foot Golf Club](/wiki/Winged_Foot_Golf_Club "Winged Foot Golf Club"), having hosted both. The PGA generally does not set up the course as difficult as the USGA does. The [PGA of America](/wiki/Professional_Golfers%27_Association_of_America "Professional Golfers' Association of America") enters into a profit-sharing agreement with the host club (except when the event is hosted by [Valhalla Golf Club](/wiki/Valhalla_Golf_Club "Valhalla Golf Club") in [Louisville, Kentucky](/wiki/Louisville,_Kentucky "Louisville, Kentucky"), a club that it owns). In a parallel with The Masters, previous winners of the PGA Championship have a lifetime invitation to compete. As well as inviting recent champions of the other three professional majors and leading players from the world rankings, the PGA Championship field is completed by qualifiers held among members of the PGA of America, the organization of club and teaching professionals that are separate from the members of the [PGA Tour](/wiki/PGA_Tour "PGA Tour"). The PGA Championship is also the only one of the four majors to invite all winners of PGA Tour events in the year preceding the tournament. Amateur golfers do not normally play on the PGA Tour, and could only qualify by winning one of the other three majors, winning a PGA Tour event while playing under a sponsor's exemption, or having a high world ranking. The PGA tends to be played in high heat and humidity that characterize the American climate in August, which often sets it apart as a challenge from (in particular) the Open Championship which precedes it, that is often played in cooler and rainy weather.

### Major champions by
nationality[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Men%27s_major_golf_championships&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Major champions by nationality")]

The table below shows the number of major championships won by golfers from
various countries. Tallies are also shown for major wins by golfers from
Europe and from the "Rest of the World" (RoW), i.e. the world excluding Europe
and the United States. The United States plays Europe in the [Ryder
Cup](/wiki/Ryder_Cup "Ryder Cup") and an International Team representing the
Rest of the World in the [Presidents Cup](/wiki/Presidents_Cup "Presidents
Cup"). The table is complete through to the 2016 season. Since the
establishment of The Masters in 1934, an American has won at least one major
every year, with the exception of 1994.

### Single round
records[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Men%27s_major_golf_championships&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Single round records")]

The record for a single round in a major championship is 62 which was recorded
by South African golfer [Branden Grace](/wiki/Branden_Grace "Branden Grace")
in the third round of the [2017 Open
Championship](/wiki/2017_Open_Championship "2017 Open Championship").

# | Player | Country | Major | Date | Course | Rnd | To par | Finish  
---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---  
1 | Grace, Branden[Branden Grace](/wiki/Branden_Grace "Branden Grace") | ![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/Flag_of_South_Africa.svg/23px-Flag_of_South_Africa.svg.png) [South Africa](/wiki/South_Africa "South Africa") | [The Open Championship](/wiki/The_Open_Championship "The Open Championship") | Jul 22, [2017](/wiki/2017_Open_Championship "2017 Open Championship") | [Royal Birkdale Golf Club](/wiki/Royal_Birkdale_Golf_Club "Royal Birkdale Golf Club") | 3 | −8 | 7000600000000000000♠T6  
  
Many players have recorded a score of 63.[27] This has occurred 32 times by 30
golfers between 1973 and 2017. [Greg Norman](/wiki/Greg_Norman "Greg Norman")
and [Vijay Singh](/wiki/Vijay_Singh "Vijay Singh") are the only golfers to
record two rounds of 63 in the majors. [Johnny Miller](/wiki/Johnny_Miller
"Johnny Miller") was the first golfer to shoot 63 in a major and was the only
golfer to shoot 63 in the final round to win a major until [Henrik
Stenson](/wiki/Henrik_Stenson "Henrik Stenson") did so as well during the
[2016 Open Championship](/wiki/2016_Open_Championship "2016 Open
Championship") at [Royal Troon Golf Club](/wiki/Royal_Troon_Golf_Club "Royal
Troon Golf Club").

## 'Player of the Year' in major
championships[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Men%27s_major_golf_championships&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: 'Player of the Year' in major championships")]

There is no official award presented to the player with the best overall
record in the four majors, although the [PGA's Player of the
Year](/wiki/PGA_Player_of_the_Year "PGA Player of the Year") system favors
performances in the major championships. Since 1984, world ranking points have
been assigned to finishes in the majors, which has allowed a calculation of
which player has earned the most ranking points in majors in a season – in
almost every year since, one of the year's major winners has either won two of
them, or has been the only player to win one and record a high finish in
another (like [Justin Leonard](/wiki/Justin_Leonard "Justin Leonard") in 1997,
[David Duval](/wiki/David_Duval "David Duval") in 2001, [Lucas
Glover](/wiki/Lucas_Glover "Lucas Glover") in 2009 or [Dustin
Johnson](/wiki/Dustin_Johnson "Dustin Johnson") in 2016), enough to finish top
of such a merit table in those years. The single exception was [Nick
Faldo](/wiki/Nick_Faldo "Nick Faldo") in 1988, whose finishes of 2nd, 3rd and
4th earned him more world ranking points than any of that year's champions
achieved during the season.

Tables are occasionally constructed for interest showing the overall scoring
records for those players who have completed all 288 holes in the majors
during a season. In the 1970s, [Jack Nicklaus](/wiki/Jack_Nicklaus "Jack
Nicklaus") led such a table in 1970–73, 1975 and 1979, with [Gary
Player](/wiki/Gary_Player "Gary Player") leading in 1974, [Raymond
Floyd](/wiki/Raymond_Floyd "Raymond Floyd") in 1976, and [Tom
Watson](/wiki/Tom_Watson_\(golfer\) "Tom Watson \(golfer\)") in 1977 and 1978.
In the 1980s a notable leader was in 1987, when [Ben
Crenshaw](/wiki/Ben_Crenshaw "Ben Crenshaw") was top of this compilation after
finishing 4th, 4th, 4th and 7th in the four majors. In total Crenshaw took
1,140 strokes, only 12 more than the sum total of the four respective
champions' scores of 1,128. Recent 'winners' of this accolade are [Pádraig
Harrington](/wiki/P%C3%A1draig_Harrington "Pádraig Harrington") in 2008, [Ross
Fisher](/wiki/Ross_Fisher "Ross Fisher") in 2009, [Phil
Mickelson](/wiki/Phil_Mickelson "Phil Mickelson") in 2010, [Charl
Schwartzel](/wiki/Charl_Schwartzel "Charl Schwartzel") in 2011, and [Adam
Scott](/wiki/Adam_Scott_\(golfer\) "Adam Scott \(golfer\)") in 2012. In 2013
Scott and fellow Australian [Jason Day](/wiki/Jason_Day "Jason Day") tied for
this accolade with a cumulative score of +2. [Rickie
Fowler](/wiki/Rickie_Fowler "Rickie Fowler") led in 2014 with −32 after top-
five finishes in all four tournaments, while in 2015 [Jordan
Spieth](/wiki/Jordan_Spieth "Jordan Spieth") led the standings by achieving
the lowest all-time cumulative score in a year of −54, one shot better than
the cumulative score of [Tiger Woods](/wiki/Tiger_Woods "Tiger Woods") in
2000. In 2016, Jason Day again led with −9, achieved despite not winning any
of the major tournaments during the year. In 2017, [Brooks
Koepka](/wiki/Brooks_Koepka "Brooks Koepka") topped the list with a cumulative
scored of −21, one shot better than [Matt Kuchar](/wiki/Matt_Kuchar "Matt
Kuchar") and [Hideki Matsuyama](/wiki/Hideki_Matsuyama "Hideki Matsuyama").

## Top ten finishes in all four modern majors in one
season[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Men%27s_major_golf_championships&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: Top ten finishes in all four modern majors in one season")]

It was rare, before the early 1960s, for the leading players from around the
world to have the opportunity to compete in all four of the 'modern' majors in
one season, because of the different qualifying criteria used in each at the
time, the costs of traveling to compete (in an era when tournament prize money
was very low, and only the champion himself would earn the chance of ongoing
endorsements), and on occasion even the conflicting scheduling of the Open and
PGA Championships. In 1937, the U.S. Ryder Cup side all competed in [The Open
Championship](/wiki/The_Open_Championship "The Open Championship"), but of
those who finished in the top ten of that event, only [Ed
Dudley](/wiki/Ed_Dudley "Ed Dudley") could claim a "top ten" finish in all
four of the majors in 1937, if his defeat in the last-16 round of that year's
PGA Championship (then at matchplay) was considered a "joint 9th" position.

Following 1960, when [Arnold Palmer](/wiki/Arnold_Palmer "Arnold Palmer")'s
narrowly failed bid to add the Open Championship to his Masters and U.S. Open
titles (and thus emulate Hogan's 1953 "triple crown") helped to establish the
concept of the modern professional "Grand Slam", it has become commonplace for
the leading players to be invited to, and indeed compete in, all four majors
each year. Even so, those who have recorded top-ten finishes in all four, in a
single year, remains a small and select group.

On 13 of the 25 occasions the feat has been achieved, the player in question
did not win a major that year – indeed, three of the players (Dudley, Sanders
and Barber) failed to win a major championship in their careers (although
Barber would go on to win five [senior
majors](/wiki/Senior_major_golf_championships "Senior major golf
championships")), and Fowler has also yet to win one (as of the end of the
2017 Open Championship).

Note: The order in which the majors were contested was inconsistent between
1895 and 1953. Since 1954, the majors have been played in their modern order
(Masters, U.S. Open, Open Championship, PGA), except 1971, when the PGA was
played prior to the Masters.

  * 1861–62: [![Scotland](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/10/Flag_of_Scotland.svg/23px-Flag_of_Scotland.svg.png)](/wiki/Scotland "Scotland") [Old Tom Morris](/wiki/Old_Tom_Morris "Old Tom Morris") 1861 Open, 1862 Open

### Most runner-up finishes in major
championships[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Men%27s_major_golf_championships&action=edit&section=31
"Edit section: Most runner-up finishes in major championships")]

For the purposes of this section a runner-up is defined as someone who either
(i) tied for the lead after 72 holes (or 36 holes in the case of the early
championships) but lost the playoff or (ii) finished alone or in a tie for
second place. In a few instances players have been involved in a playoff for
the win or for second place prize money and have ended up taking the third
prize (e.g. [1870 Open Championship](/wiki/1870_Open_Championship "1870 Open
Championship"), [1966 Masters Tournament](/wiki/1966_Masters_Tournament "1966
Masters Tournament")). These players are still regarded as being runners-up.
For [match play](/wiki/Match_play "Match play") PGA Championships up to 1957
the runner-up is the losing finalist.

Along with his record 18 major victories, [Jack Nicklaus](/wiki/Jack_Nicklaus
"Jack Nicklaus") also holds the record for most runner-up finishes in major
championships, with 19, including a record 7 at the Open Championship. [Phil
Mickelson](/wiki/Phil_Mickelson "Phil Mickelson") has the second most with 11
runner-up finishes after the 2016 Open Championship, which includes a record 6
runner-up finishes at the U.S. Open, the one major he has never won. [Arnold
Palmer](/wiki/Arnold_Palmer "Arnold Palmer") had 10 second places, including
three in the major he never won, the PGA Championship. There have been three
golfers with 8 runner-up finishes – [Sam Snead](/wiki/Sam_Snead "Sam Snead"),
[Greg Norman](/wiki/Greg_Norman "Greg Norman") and [Tom
Watson](/wiki/Tom_Watson_\(golfer\) "Tom Watson \(golfer\)"). Norman shares
the distinction of having lost playoffs in each of the four majors with [Craig
Wood](/wiki/Craig_Wood_\(golfer\) "Craig Wood \(golfer\)") (who lost the 1934
PGA final – at match play – on the second extra hole).

  * [![United States](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/a4/Flag_of_the_United_States.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_United_States.svg.png)](/wiki/United_States "United States") [Jack Nicklaus](/wiki/Jack_Nicklaus "Jack Nicklaus"): 19 (1960–1983)
  * [![United States](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/a4/Flag_of_the_United_States.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_United_States.svg.png)](/wiki/United_States "United States") [Phil Mickelson](/wiki/Phil_Mickelson "Phil Mickelson"): 11 (1999–2016)
  * [![United States](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/a4/Flag_of_the_United_States.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_United_States.svg.png)](/wiki/United_States "United States") [Arnold Palmer](/wiki/Arnold_Palmer "Arnold Palmer"): 10 (1960–1970)
  * [![United States](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/a4/Flag_of_the_United_States.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_United_States.svg.png)](/wiki/United_States "United States") [Sam Snead](/wiki/Sam_Snead "Sam Snead"): 8 (1937–1957)
  * [![Australia](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b9/Flag_of_Australia.svg/23px-Flag_of_Australia.svg.png)](/wiki/Australia "Australia") [Greg Norman](/wiki/Greg_Norman "Greg Norman"): 8 (1984–1996)
  * [![United States](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/a4/Flag_of_the_United_States.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_United_States.svg.png)](/wiki/United_States "United States") [Tom Watson](/wiki/Tom_Watson_\(golfer\) "Tom Watson \(golfer\)"): 8 (1978–2009)
